ANNEX

I. Questions to the Council

 

Question No 19 by Magda Aelvoet (H−0586/96)

Subject: Low‐level military flights over the territory of the Innu people in Canada

Various Member States of the European Union – Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, the Netherlands and Belgium – take part in low‐level military flying over the territory inhabited by the indigenous Innu people in Labrador, Canada. In so doing, they cause noise and air pollution that is a serious threat to the way of life of this indigenous people. Has the Council ever considered this matter, and have alternatives to low‐level flying over this area been sought?

Answer

The Council has never been called upon to discuss the problem mentioned in the honourable Member's question, because this particular matter is one for the bilateral relations between Canada (the country in which the region overflown is located) and each of the countries to which the aircraft overflying that region belong.

The honourable Member will therefore understand that the Council is in no position to give an answer to the question he asks.

Question No 20 by Mihail Papayannakis (H−0588/96)

Subject: EU‐Turkey customs union

What stage has been reached in implementing the customs union between the European Union and Turkey and what is the Council's assessment of its results so far and of its immediate prospects?

Answer

Following the European Parliament's agreement on 13 December 1995, the decision to implement the final phase of Customs Union came into effect as planned, on 31 December 1995.

The statutory orders envisaged by that decision have been established. The joint committee has met on two occasions and examined a number of special issues relating to the situation regarding exports to the Community and to Turkey, about which no previous consultations had taken place before Customs Union had come into force. The Council is still awaiting the European Parliament's opinion on the procedure for approving the common position within the framework of the joint committee on Customs Union before going ahead with its own approval. Experts from Turkey also sit on a number of technical committees: the committee on textiles, the customs committee and the committee on nomenclature, to facilitate the correct operation of Customs Union.

It is still too early to make any final assessment of the trade and economic consequences of the first six months during which Customs Union has operated, in the absence of facts and figures both from the Community and from Turkey. However, we can say that on the whole, Customs Union is working satisfactorily. Goods are moving in both directions without encountering obstacles to these transactions, whether or not related to customs duties or technical factors. The results will depend both on the behaviour of the economic agencies and on the flow of the investments made. It is also clear that the unstable political situation in Turkey since Customs Union came into force has had negative consequences at an economic level, and consequently for Customs Union as well, particularly where foreign investment is concerned.

Yet, the Council considers that Customs Union is an important achievement in relations with Turkey, which must be preserved and developed, continuing the efforts to harmonise the various sectors, as for example industrial regulations and specifications. The European Council of Florence in any case stressed that it gives priority to promoting and deepening relations with Turkey.

Question No 21 by Liam Hyland (H−0592/96)

Subject: Priorities in agriculture and rural development

Can the President‐in‐Office indicate the Council's priorities in the agricultural and rural development sector during the term in office of the Irish presidency?

Answer

I should first like to draw attention to the fact that each President of the Council meets the relevant committee of the European Parliament at the beginning of the term of office to present the work programme and that, in addition, the Foreign Affairs Minister addresses Parliament at its first plenary session.

The work programme for agriculture will be presented in detail to the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development by the Irish Minister for Agriculture, Mr Yates, in September 1996.

Nevertheless, I can already outline to you the broad lines of this programme.

A major priority of the Irish presidency will be to achieve a satisfactory resolution of the difficulties in the beef sector arising from BSE, including a restoration of consumer confidence in beef and changes in the market organization which will better suit the sector in longer term.

The finalisation of the 1996/97 prices package and the reform of the fruit and vegetables sector on which the June Council meeting failed to reach agreement will also be given priority attention.

A further priority will be to secure a satisfactory outcome to the debate within the Council on the reports which the Commission is required to carry out on the application of the quota system in the sheepmeat sector and of the quotas transfer and national reserve arrangement for the suckler cow premium and to bring any resultant Commission proposals to a satisfactory conclusion.

Priority will also be given to progressing existing and projected proposals from the Commission on wine, bananas, olive oil, tobacco and potatoes.

Other priorities will be the finalisation of a number of proposals in the veterinary area relating to veterinary harmonisation, food safety, animal welfare and trade and the siting of a new EU Veterinary Agency in Ireland.

A conference on all aspects of rural development will be held in Cork in November.

Question No 22 by Pat Gallagher (H−0593/96)

Subject: Fishery Policy priorities

Can the President‐in‐Office indicate the Council's priorities in the fisheries sector during the term in office of the Irish presidency?

Answer

The work programme of the Irish presidency will include the usual end‐of‐year regulations concerning:

‐ TACs and quotas and related measures for 1997;

‐ third country relations including fisheries arrangements with Norway, the Faroe Islands, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland and Russia;

‐ negotiations with Norway of new managements regimes for herring and mackerel;

‐ possibly the conclusion of new fisheries arrangements with the Baltic States;

‐ fisheries arrangements in the NAFO Regulatory Area and the Baltic Sea (IBSFC);

‐ prices for 1997.

The Irish presidency gives priority status to the following proposals from the Commission:

‐ adoption of a new regulation on technical conservation measures;

‐ improved control measures, including a satellite‐based vessel monitoring system and an integrated computer network;

‐ adoption of the Fourth Multiannual Guidance Programmes for the fishing fleets;

‐ questions relating to the Common Market Organization, such as the fixing of reference prices for fish products for the 1997 season and the establishment of common marketing standards for certain fish products.

The President‐in‐Office will appear before the Fisheries Committee of the European Parliament on Monday 22 July 1996 to give a more detailed outline of the priorities of the Irish presidency.

Question No 24 by Per Gahrton (H−0596/96)

Subject: The peace process in the Middle East

In the special declaration on the peace process in the Middle East issued at the Florence Summit the European Council expresses its strong support for a continued peace process. At the same time the statement contains not a single word of criticism or concern at the new Israeli Prime Minister's freely‐stated rejection of the cornerstones of the peace process: the return of occupied Arab territory in return for peace, and genuine and complete self‐determination for the Palestinians. Is this silence because the Council has information that Mr Netanyahu does not intended to fulfil his election promises? Is the Council engaged in quiet diplomacy to enable the Israeli Prime Minister to make a constructive contribution to the peace process? If not, what action is the Council planning to restart the peace process?

Answer

The Declaration by the European Council in Florence on the Middle East peace process called on all parties to re‐engage themselves in the peace process, to respect and implement fully all the agreements already reached and to resume negotiations as soon as possible on the basis of the principles already accepted by all parties under the Madrid and Oslo frameworks.

It further recalled that self‐determination for the Palestinians and land for peace were key principles on which a successful conclusion of the negotiations should be based.

I would like to stress that the declaration was addressed to all parties, meaning also the incoming Israeli Government.

It would be inappropriate for the European Union to prejudge the policy of the government on the basis of statements made before taking office. It should be judged by actions rather than words. But our expectation is that the new Israeli Government will fully implement all agreements concluded on behalf of Israel by the previous government.

Question No 25 by Friedrich Wolf (H−0603/96)

Subject: EU support for the new Bundesländer

Is the Council aware what efforts are being made in Germany to reduce EU support for the new Bundesländer? What opportunities does it see for taking action itself to ensure that the new federal regions' special need of support as areas in the process of transformation continues to be recognized?

Answer

When the Council adopted the regulations on the Structural Funds, it entrusted their management to the Commission.

The Commission decides on the Community financing for the various measures taken in each country, in partnership with the Member State concerned, in compliance with the legislation in force.

The Council does not take part in this exercise; it is therefore not competent to reply to the question put by the honourable Member.

The Council feels bound to point out, however, that the new German Länder are included in the list of regions whose development is lagging behind. That list is valid until 31 December 1999.

Question No 26 by Yannos Kranidiotis (H−0607/96)

Subject: Irish presidency's intentions regarding EU involvement in the situation in Cyprus

During the Italian presidency, Ambassador Di Roberto was appointed special representative on the Cyprus question. Unfortunately, this initiative did not produce practical results. On the contrary, measures taken by other Member States at the same time undermined rather than strengthened the Italian initiative.

Will the Council and the Irish presidency say what position they intend to adopt on the active involvement of the EU in endeavours to resolve the situation in Cyprus and, in particular:

will the Irish presidency appoint its own observer to replace Mr Di Roberto; will it advocate the appointment of an EU Council liaison representative to coordinate all the initiatives aimed at resolving the Cyprus question, whose mandate will extend beyond the end of the Irish presidency; when will it put the matter to the Council for a decision, and what is its response to the European Parliament's proposal for joint EU action on the Cyprus question?

Answer

The prospect of accession to the EU by Cyprus offers an opportunity and incentive to seek a political settlement to the Cyprus question. It was in this context that the Italian presidency appointed a representative for Cyprus, Ambassador Di Roberto. We would like to express our appreciation and our thanks to Ambassador Di Roberto for the dedicated and consistent efforts he has made on behalf of the EU in seeking, in very difficult circumstances, to advance the prospects of a political solution. As EU presidency, Ireland will seek to continue the Union's support to contribute to the international effort to make progress towards an agreed settlement between the two communities on the island.

Following consultation with our EU partners, the Irish presidency announced at the General Affairs Council the appointment of Ambassador Kester Heaslip as our representative for Cyprus. A consistent and complementary approach by the international community is obviously essential and we will seek to ensure that the EU closely coordinates with other interested parties. We will consult with partners to consider how the Union's approach on Cyprus might be further developed when Ambassador Heaslip's recommendations are available.

Question No 27 by Anne McIntosh (H−0430/96)

Subject: Intrastat

Is the Council aware of the burdens placed on SMEs by the obligations of the Intrastat system?

Will the Council consider shifting the financial burden from the providers of the information to the users of Intrastat?

Would not a privatized system be more market‐responsive and ensure that the most wanted information was made available to users of Intrastat statistics?

Answer

The Council is of the opinion that the obligations of the Intrastat system cannot be considered as a burden placed on SME's. However, the Council is aware of the need to examine ways of simplifying the Intrastat rules. At an informal meeting of the Ministers responsible for the Internal Market in Rome in February this year there was general support for the launch of a pilot scheme to assess how best to reduce the burden on business of single market rules in particular sectors. The Council identified four areas including Intrastat.

The Commission has responded by establishing a pilot project entitled SLIM (Simpler Legislation for the Internal Market) which is described in detail in the Commission's communication to the Council and the European Parliament of 13 May 1996. At its session of 28 May 1996, the Internal Market Council broadly endorsed this initiative and highlighted the need to focus particular attention on Intrastat. The Council anticipates receiving a report from the Commission on the outcome of the project towards the end of the year and will consider any legislative or other proposals which might accompany or follow it. At this juncture it would be premature to speculate on possible specific changes such as the ideas put forward in the second and third questions posed by the honourable Member.

Question No 28 by Eva Kjer Hansen (H−0486/96)

Subject: Convention for the protection of the Communities' financial interests

Does the Council consider it acceptable that none of the Member States has ratified the Convention for the protection of the Communities' financial interests, which was signed on 26 July 1995?

What action will it take to ensure that the Convention is ratified by all Member States by the end of 1996?

Answer

1. The Council attaches the utmost importance to the fact that the Member States should complete as soon as possible the internal procedures allowing them to accede to the Conventions which the Council has unanimously recommended, pursuant to Article K.3(2)(c) of the Treaty on European Union, for adoption in accordance with the Member States' respective constitutional requirements.

2. However, the Member States alone are responsible for completing these internal procedures.

3. On the subject of the Convention for the protection of the Communities' financial interests, which was drawn up by the Council on 26 July 1995, it should be noted that the Council has before it initiatives designed to supplement the Convention by one or more additional protocols which, once drawn up by the Council, would also have to be submitted to a national adoption procedure. It would be up to each Member State to decide whether to start its internal procedures for the Convention alone, or whether to wait until any protocols were attached before doing this.

II. Questions to the Commission

 

Question No 50 by Friedrich Wolf (H−0604/96)

Subject: Support for small and medium‐sized enterprises

Does the Commission know how in practice structural support affects the chances of small and medium enterprises receiving support? Has the Commission noticed a perceptible improvement in this regard, or has it noticed a deterioration? Can it break its findings down by type of enterprise? What can and will the Commission do, if anything, to improve support for innovative and environmentally and socially responsible undertakings geared to regional employment?

Answer

The structural funds provide support to SMEs through instruments of regional economic development policy, such as the Single Programming Documents (SPDs) or Community Support Frameworks (CSFs) and many Community Initiatives.

The SPDs and the CSFs contain specific measures (assistance towards services, financing of transfer of technologies, improvement of access for enterprises to the capital market, direct aid to investment) for SMEs but do not favour any particular industrial sector or type of company. ‚De minimis’ rules are also implemented to simplify and facilitate the access of SMEs to financial supports. The new programming period 1997‐1999 under Objective 2 will include measures such as actions in the field of human resources, the link between investment and job‐creation, actions for research, development and innovation and exploitation of eco‐products, environmental services and technologies and energy saving measures and improved production processes.

The percentage of structural funds which goes to SMEs depends on Member States priorities and therefore differs from Member State to Member State. However, in some areas this figure can easily reach 20 % of total available funds. (125 measures for a total of ECU 2bn have been identified in the Greek CSF). Most CSFs include a specific axis dedicated to SMEs such as in the Spanish case which envisages an allocation of almost ECU 2800m for the development of economic structures; 35 % of this sum goes to SMEs and 53 % is spent on indirect actions for SMEs.

Many Community Initiatives (RESIDER, RECHAR, RETEX, KONVER, SME and ADAPT) contain specific guidelines in favour of the SMEs.

With respect to the current Community Initiatives programming period (1994‐1999) it is still too early to evaluate the results. However, it is clear from the evaluations of the Community Initiatives which were implemented during the previous programming period that support was provided to SMEs for many innovative and environmentally sound projects. The most obvious examples are the STRIDE, TELEMATIC and PRISMA programmes. The new SME Community Initiative has built on the success of these programmes. Under this Initiative the Commission has retained a small proportion of the funds to be spent exclusively on transnational measures with the Community. Similarly an Info‐pack will be published by the Commission to give a full guide for SMEs to the type of funding available for SMEs under the various structural funds programmes.

In the framework of its decision of 8 May 1996 concerning the allocation of the financial reserve of the Community initiatives, the Commission approved the reinforcement and extension of the industrial Initiatives of reconversion and adopted a new strand ADAPT ‚Bis’ (Building the Information Society) designed to contribute to the adaptation of the workforce to industrial change and to improve the workings of the labour market.

Question No 51 by Michael Elliott (H−0609/96)

Subject: Konver II‐Measure 5

Owing to the mobility of the west London population it is inappropriate to restrict Measure 5 funding under the Konver II initiative solely to individuals who have been directly affected by job losses in the defence industry.

Areas such as Hillingdon and Hounslow have had serious employment effects from the downsizing of the defence sector. However, Konver activity in these areas will be a tenth of what was initially foreseen, owing to this inflexible approach. Will the Commission ensure that the criteria for Measure 5 of the Konver II initiative will be reviewed at the earliest opportunity?

Question No 52 by Shaun Spiers (H−0610/96)

Subject: Konver II‐Measure 5

Does the Commission agree that if local authorities were able to use Konver II Measure 5 funding for training and retraining on regionally‐based projects, rather than projects aimed at individuals who have been directly affected by military sector cuts, then the take‐up of Konver funding would be greater and the principle of subsidiarity better employed?

Question No 53 by David Thomas (H−0611/96)

Subject: Konver II‐Measure 5

With regard to Measure 5 of the Konver II Community initiative, does the Commission agree that retraining projects which have to pin point individuals rather than localities are more difficult to put into effect and therefore lead to even longer delays in European funding and a lower take‐up?

Question No 54 by Richard Howitt (H−0612/96)

Subject: Konver II‐Measure 5

If funding for training and retraining under Measure 5 of the Konver II initiative were aimed at regions affected by military downsizing – rather than restricted to individuals who have lost or are about to lose defence industry jobs in those areas – this Community Initiative would have a sharper regional impact.

Does the Commission therefore agree that, with its current restrictions, Measure 5 of the Konver II initiative sits uncomfortably with the general regional strategy of the Konver II Community initiative?

Question No 55 by Robert Evans (H−0614/96)

Subject: Konver II – Measure 5

Measure 5 of the Konver II initiative is targeted at individuals directly affected by military downsizing. Does this not prevent a pre‐emptive regional policy approach to training and retraining under Measure 5 of the Konver II Community initiative?

Joint answer

The description of activities eligible under measure 5 in the United Kingdom Konver programme (Training and retraining) corresponds to the original proposal submitted by the United Kingdom authorities in February 1995. The Commission agreed to the definition of target groups envisaged for this measure, considering that it fitted the objectives of the Konver initiative. This reflected a number of principles:

‐ Firstly, the specificity of the Community Initiatives requires Konver to focus on facilitating the conversion of economic activities linked to the defence sector. It is the need to accelerate this conversion that has given rise to Konver.

‐ Secondly, there is a need for an integrated approach which combines the generation of new economic activity with adequate training and retraining for those groups most affected by the decline of defence and military employment.

‐ Finally, Konver must be complementary to activities under other programmes, in particular Objectives 3 and 4 and Community Initiatives such as Adapt and Employment.

It seems premature at this early point in the life of the programme to review this issue. If, however, it was thought necessary, the relaxation of conditions of eligibility such as the one proposed would be possible only on the basis of a decision by the Monitoring Committee and subsequent endorsement by the Commission. In such a case it would have to be clear that any such training actions were part of a local strategy for the diversification of those areas most dependent on the defence sector. The Konver initiative does not provide for the training of the unemployed not previously employed in the defence sector.

Question No 56 by Arlene McCarthy (H−0613/96)

Subject: Privatized utilities

Can the Commissioner give an update on the current state of the Commission's investigation into the payment of ERDF grants to privatized utilities? Since the Commission launched its investigation eighteen months ago several mergers of privatized utilities are to take place, namely Severn Trent and South‐West Water, both of which have received substantial sums from the ERDF. Tyne Port authority is to be sold off, again having benefited from over £6 million in Eurogrants. Can the Commissioner state whether a claw‐back mechanism exists, should the grants not fall within the terms of the Structural Fund regulations?

Answer

The Commission's investigation covers in principle all public sector assets which have received structural fund support and have later been transferred to private ownership. The investigation relates to all Member States. However, detailed enquiries have focused on cases in the United Kingdom, because the process of privatization is furthest advanced there.

The Commission last wrote to the United Kingdom authorities in February 1996, asking questions about a range of privatizations that have taken place involving projects that the structural funds have co‐financed. It received a reply on 21 June and the details provided are now being analysed. The Commission is also engaged in ongoing correspondence with the United Kingdom Government concerning the privatization of British Coal Enterprise.

With any grant‐aided project, repayment of grant may be necessary if it is discovered that a significant change in its nature has occurred during its lifetime which is incompatible with the conditions and use agreed when grant was originally provided. In such cases, any sum to be repaid would take into account the degree to which conditions for the use of the asset had been changed and also the period during which the asset had been used for the grant‐aidable purpose before the change had taken place,

Question No 57 by Allan Macartney (H−0511/96)

Subject: Anti‐personnel mines

Can the Commission confirm that the allocation for budget line B7‐615 relating to mine‐clearing operations will be earmarked solely for mine‐clearing operations in the former Yugoslavia, at the expense of operations necessitated by the situations in many other countries, including Angola, Mozambique, Afghanistan and Cambodia?

Could the Commission also say whether it intends to take account in some other way of the mine‐clearing requirements of those countries (particularly, Mozambique and Angola), as set out in the European Parliament resolution of 29 June 1995?

Answer

During the period 1995‐96 some ECU 50m from the European Community budget, as well as from the European Development Fund (EDF) is being devoted to mine clearance activity around the world and the greater part of this, over ECU 40m, is supporting mine clearance actions in developing countries (in particular Afghanistan, Angola, Cambodia, Mozambique and Zimbabwe).

The Commission continues to draw on a number of budget lines for such activities and on the EDF, and the ECU 3m from the common foreign and security policy funds, contributed to the United Nations Voluntary Trust Fund for Assistance in Mine Clearance at the end of 1995 is also to be used for mine clearance actions in Angola and Mozambique.

As far as the B7‐615 budget line is concerned, the Commission wishes to use approximately ECU 6‐8m of this for mine clearance actions in Bosnia‐Herzegovina, an area in urgent need of assistance, where the Commission has identified four particular projects which it wishes to take forward as quickly as possible. It is now engaged in tender procedures for two of these. In addition, a number of projects in the ACP countries are being identified for possible funding from the new budget line, in such areas as training in detection and neutralization of explosive devices and mine accidents prevention.

From a practical point of view, and through its political efforts, the EU stands at the forefront of the most effective international actions to overcome the anti‐personnel mines tragedy, particularly in the developing world. The Commission is playing a major part in this.

Question No 58 by John Iversen (H−0516/96)

Subject: Agreement between German power companies and the Danish Ministry of Economic Affairs on the subsidizing of electricity generated on the basis of lignite.

In what way does the binding agreement entitled ‚Energiekonsensrunde Ost’, signed in Erfurt on 31 January 1996, contravene EU competition law?

How does the Commission plan to enforce current EU competition law in view of national arrangements along the lines of the above agreement?

Answer

Following a previous parliamentary question (P−850/96) the Commission has been informed of the existence of the agreements within the ‚Energiekonsensrunden Ost’. According to the information provided, these agreements have been reached among the Federal Government, the local governments in East Germany and electricity producers in East Germany in order to favour the use of lignite in electricity production. The Commission has sent a formal request for information to the German authorities concerning these agreements.

The honourable Member also refers to an agreement between German electricity producers and the Danish Ministry of Economics. The Commission has raised the matter with the German authorities and requested further information.

The Commission will conclude on the compatibility of these agreements with the state aid rules laid down in Articles 92 and 93 of the EC Treaty and with the rules applying to undertakings laid down in Article 85 and 86 when the requested information is submitted and fully examined.

Question No 59 by Julio Añoveros Trias de Bes (H−0518/96)

Subject: EU cooperation with the Inter‐American Development Bank

Does the Commission think that the EU development policy is adequately coordinated with that of the Inter‐American Development Bank? What reply did the Commission receive from the IADB Costa Rica to the Union's request for the ALA 91/93 programme to be linked up with the SOAGAM Programme? Is the Commission aware of how damaging any lack of coordination between the institutions is both to the development programmes and to the Union's image worldwide?

Answer

The Commission is aware of the need to make Community action more effective, and in that context it attaches great importance to coordinating its activities, especially with the Inter‐American Development Bank (IDB).

The establishment of closer relations with the IDB is justified by the fact that the bank, which enjoys the active support of the Latin American States, is one of the indispensable factors for cooperation in that region.

The additionality between the possible courses of action taken by the two institutions seems clear, in so far as they share common objectives and have established similar priorities: support for the democratic process and defence of human rights, combatting poverty and social exclusion, and supporting private sector development. The Commission thus considers it expedient to take advantage of these additionalities by stepping up the level of dialogue and cooperation on a reciprocal basis, and as a function of the action priorities and available resources of each of these institutions.

A good level of dialogue already exists, sustained by regular contacts between the representatives of the European Commission and of the IDB, both at their head offices in Brussels and Washington and in the field, through the agency of the Commission's delegations and the representatives of the IDB. Furthermore, the scale of the joint activities is substantial: since 1995 the Commission has committed more than ECU 30 million in favour of the IDB to cofinance activities in various sectors, especially support for the development of the microenterprise, the establishment of a special fund for European technical assistance, health and the promotion of human resources.

The matter raised by the honourable Member refers to the programmes for processing hospital waste, ALA 91/93, the Commission's ‚Regional programme for the collection and processing of wastes originating from hospitals’, and SOAGAM, the IDB's ‚Environmental Improvement System for the Greater Metropolitan Area’. Following an invitation from an external adviser to the IDB, the Commission delegation on Costa Rica contacted the IDB office in that country with a view to studying the benefits of cooperation. This consultation has produced no tangible results, the local office of the IDB having, as yet, reached no conclusion as to the value of establishing coordination in connection with these programmes. This fact will not affect the quality of relations between the Commission and the Inter‐American Development Bank.

Question No 60 by Ivar Virgin (H−0522/96)

Subject: Swedish derogations from EU environmental legislation

During its membership negotiations, Sweden secured derogations from EU rules on the free movement of goods, namely chemicals, relating to levels of protection and classification and labelling requirements for allergenic and carcinogenic substances. The derogations also cover limits on the use of arsenic, cadmium, organotin compounds and pentachlorophenol and are to apply for four years, i.e. until 1 January 1999. It is hoped in Sweden that, during that period, EU legislation will be brought more into line with Swedish legislation.

Will EU standards be raised in time, so that Sweden does not have to lower its environmental standards?

Answer

The work within the Commission with regard to the review clause in the Act of Accession for Austria, Finland and Sweden is well under way. The Commission fully assumes its obligations to review the relevant provisions of Community legislation which do not apply to the three new Member States during a period of four years. Where necessary, the review will aim at raising the existing Community standards in the fields concerned.

At present work is performed and discussions are held at all levels in order to complete the process before the end of the transitional period while achieving acceptable solutions for all parties.

The Commission is currently ensuring that all substances and preparations which should be subject to a review are put on the agenda for the discussions to take place in the relevant expert groups where the aspects to be reviewed are being discussed on the basis of scientific data. This includes the classification and labelling requirements for allergenic and carcinogenic substances, mentioned by the honourable Member.

First results have already been achieved, for instance with regard to Directive 67/548/EEC on the classification, packaging and labelling of dangerous substances. The Commission proposal for the 22nd adaptation of this Directive to technical progress will shortly be formally adopted as a Commission Directive. The committee voted unanimously in favour of the Commission proposal, which includes about 20 % of the substances to be considered (13 for Austria and 11 for Sweden).

As regards the restrictions on the marketing and use of cadmium, arsenic, organostannic compounds and PCP, it has emerged that stringent measures, of the type sought by Sweden and the other new Member States, cannot be introduced without agreement on detailed risk assessments, focusing on exposure scenarios and including, where necessary, also the chemical substitutes of these substances. The substances in question will therefore be included in the third priority list of Council Regulation No 793/93 on the evaluation and the control of the risks of existing substances, provided that the precise chemical identity of these substances is established and the producers and importers of these substances are identified. These risk assessments and additional technical and economic information will form the basis for the discussions in the competent working group.

For those cases where the Directives in question are under revision, the Commission endeavours to take into account the new Member States legitimate concerns.

More detailed studies and/or scientific evidence, which partly should be provided by the new Member States themselves, are needed as a basis for Commission proposals in some instances.

In order to ensure proper communication with and information from the new Member States, the Commission held a high‐level meeting with representatives of the new Member States on 20 June 1996. It was concluded that in general preparatory work is well under way for all directives to be reviewed. During the meeting, progress made, problems encountered, further strategy and timetable for the review process were discussed. With the outcome of this meeting and regularly held meetings of its kind in the future, a firm basis has been established for the continuation of the process.

Question No 61 by Frederik Willockx (H−0524/96)

Subject: Support for the dredging industry

The Commission has authorized the Netherlands to provide state aid to its maritime industry. In practice, this results in dredgers being accorded tax concessions. This constitutes aid to an industry which is under heavy pressure, particularly within the Community. Can the Commission authorize other Member States likewise to support their maritime industry, and particularly dredging companies, by means of tax concessions? Would it not be worth specifically including dredging in the revision of the rules on shipping? Would not European rules be appropriate, as a means of ensuring that the Member States do not compete with one another through social and fiscal dumping?

Answer

In applying State aid rules to the maritime sector, the Commission has accepted that EC fleets face considerable competition from vessels registered in third countries which can benefit from low company taxation, low wage costs and low social charges. This has led to flagging‐out of Community vessels and a loss of jobs for EC seafarers. Measures aiming at the maintenance of ships under Community flags and the employment, to the highest possible proportion of Community seafarers on board ships are, therefore, considered to be in the common interest of the Community. Inter alia, the approval of aid measures on social security and seafarers' income tax, reducing manning costs borne by shipping companies and resulting from the operation of ships registered in the Community is part of a long‐standing Community policy.

In 1995, the Netherlands Government modified the State aid package which supports its shipping industry. One part of this scheme is the alleviation of fiscal charges relating to seafarers on board Dutch‐flagged vessels, including dredgers. A number of other Member States also allow fiscal alleviation for seafarers serving on board ships flying their flag.

The State aid rules do not, at present, distinguish between different sectors of shipping. However, if the Commission becomes aware of distortion of competition affecting trading conditions to an extent contrary to the common interest which is the result of a State aid scheme, it will take the necessary action to resolve problems.

Question No 62 by Otto von Habsburg (H−0525/96)

Subject: Apparent discrimination against non‐Belgian EU citizens by the Belgian police

Recently there have been many speed checks on Belgian roads and motorways which affect only foreign vehicles, while Belgians continue to drive without hindrance. The police cars have posted in them the fines for infringements in the various EU currencies. In cases of non‐payment the vehicle is impounded.

Can the Commission discover from the competent office whether instructions on this matter have been received from Belgian government authorities?

Is such conduct acceptable from a state which is seeking to establish the capital of Europe on its territory?

Is the discrimination against EU citizens by comparison with the nationals of an individual state compatible with the spirit of the European Union?

Answer

The Commission is not aware of any official discrimination against non‐Belgian Community drivers at speed limit controls on Belgian roads.

It is clear that any form of discrimination would be an infringement of the EC Treaty.

Question No 63 by Charlotte Cederschiöld (H−0526/96)

Subject: Unemployment benefit in another EU country

The Commission's answer to my question No H−0106/96(1) was that it did not approve of Sweden's requirement that an unemployed person must have collected unemployment benefit in Sweden for three months before being allowed to look for work in another country while retaining the right to unemployment benefit. The Swedish authorities claim that they need that amount of time to check that there are no jobs available in Sweden for the unemployed before they are allowed to travel abroad. This position is in stark contrast to the Commission's intention to allow the unemployed freedom of movement with no waiting period. What measures will the Commission take to press ahead with this matter and what is its timetable?

Answer

As indicated in the reply to the honourable Member's previous question on this subject, the Commission is aware of the condition imposed by the Swedish authorities that a person must have been unemployed for three months before being eligible to seek employment in another Member State while retaining their right to Swedish unemployment benefits.

The applicable provision of Community law, Article 69 of Regulation 1408/71, states that a person must have been unemployed for four weeks prior to his or her departure to another Member State to look for work.

The Commission wrote to the Permanent Representation to the European Union on 8 May to obtain the views of the Swedish Government on this issue. A reply has not yet been received.

However, the honourable Member is informed that in the Swedish Parliament on 26 June, Margareta Winberg, the Minister of Labour, stated that with the agreement of the Swedish Government, the Labour Market Board would change its interpretation of Article 69 to conform with the position of the Commission. The Commission looks forward to written confirmation of the Swedish Government's recent statement.

Question No 64 by Nikitas Kaklamanis (H−0527/96)

Subject: Participation by Turkey in the TACIS programme

It is well known that, since 1992, the Oil and Gas Pipeline Management Programme for the extraction and transport to Western Europe of energy sources in the Caucasus and Central Asia has formed part of the TACIS programme.

In the first conference on this subject held on 20‐24 December 1995, it was decided to set up a working group which met for the first time on 17‐19 April 1996, in which Turkey was also represented, although it is not a beneficiary (or eligible for aid) under this programme. In view of this:

Has it been decided that Turkey is entitled to TACIS funding? If not, why was it represented at the working group in April?

If so, for what projects and in the territory of what country has Turkey submitted studies eligible for funding under the programme?

Answer

The beneficiaries of the project EREG 92.02 ‚Oil & Gas Pipeline Management in NIS’ are: Kazakhstan, Kyrgystan, Uzbekistan, Tadjikistan, Turkmenistan, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Moldova, Georgia, Ukraine, Belarus. Although Russia is an eligible TACIS country, the Russian Federation has up to now participated as an observer. This situation may change in the future.

This project is intended to facilitate transit of oil and gas between the beneficiaries and between them and the European markets. Cooperation between producers in Central Asia and the Caspian basin, European consumers and actual or potential transit countries, including Central and East European countries and Turkey, will be essential for the success of the project. Representatives of these countries as well as international financing institutions, professional organizations and the International Energy Agency accordingly participated at the conference on oil and gas pipeline management held in November 1995 in Brussels, which concluded the first phase of the project as well as at the meeting of the Working Group set up by the November conference. This Working Group met in Brussels in April 1996.

The Technical Programme defined by the Working Group during its last meeting is addressed exclusively to the beneficiaries, ie. the Newly Independent States. No funds will be accorded to Turkey. No pipelines on the territory of Turkey will be included in the Programme.

Regarding the participation of natural or legal persons from PHARE or Mediterranean countries in the project, any such participation would be considered on a case‐by‐case basis and in full accordance with the TACIS Regulation.

Question No 65 by David Martin (H−0530/96)

Subject: Transposition of the Time‐Share Directive into Member States' law

Would the Commission outline what steps it will be taking to ensure a speedy transposition of the Time‐Share Directive (COM(93)487 final)(2) into Member States' law?

Answer

The Commission can inform the honourable Member that Directive 94/47/CE of 26 October 1994 on ‚the protection of purchasers in respect of certain aspects of contracts relating to the purchase of the right to use immovable properties on a timeshare basis’ provides in its Article 12 that the Member States are obliged to implement the directive not later than 30 months after its publication in the Official Journal. Hence the Member States must bring into force the laws, regulations and administrative provisions necessary for them to comply with the directive by the end of April 1997.

In its role as ‚guardian of the Treaties’ the Commission has to observe the correct application of Community law. In order to ensure the timely implementation of secondary Community law, the Commission sends within two months after the adoption of a directive a letter to the national authorities demanding the notification of national transposition measures including a table which indicates the national provisions corresponding to the provision of the directive. A second letter is sent to the Member States six months before the expiry of the delay as foreseen in the directive.

Following this procedure the Commission communicated to the Member States the first so‐called ‚reminder letter’ concerning the Timeshare Directive in spring 1995, in which the national authorities were asked to provide ample information on the relevant implementation provision.

However, until now the Commission has not received any formal notification from the Member States.

The second ‚reminder letter’ will be prepared by the Commission during the autumn of this year.

Question No 67 by Riccardo Nencini (H−0533/96)

The rights of consumers must be safeguarded at all times and in all circumstances, and they should be enabled to make informed choices.

The fact that pre‐baked and frozen bread is sold loose in Italy constitutes a violation of the consumer's right to information.

Does the Commission intend to reaffirm the obligation to comply with the rules laid down in Directives 89/395(4) , 89/396(5) and 91/238(6) , which are apparently being ignored in Italy?

Answer

The Commission does not consider that the marketing of pre‐baked quick‐frozen bread is liable to mislead the consumer provided that the provisions related to labelling are respected. The Commission has not hitherto become aware of instances in which the legislation governing the labelling of foodstuffs, to which the honourable Member refers in his question, has not been correctly observed in Italy.

Question No 68 by Roberto Mezzaroma (H−0536/96)

Subject: New use for the former Montalto di Castro nuclear power‐station

Increasingly strong rumours are spreading in informed quarters that the former Montalto di Castro nuclear power‐station may be used in future as a large liquid methane depot serving the northern European area.

The proposed new use of the existing installations would not remove the potential dangers of serious accidents and irreparable damage to local populations and the immediate environment.

Will the Commission therefore make inquiries forthwith in order to ascertain whether the above possibility in fact exists? If the rumours are true, will it hold discussions in the appropriate forums in order to bring the necessary clarification?

Answer

The question concerns the debate about the possibility that the ex‐nuclear facility (never commissioned) at Montalto di Castro will be used as a location for large‐scale storage of liquefied natural gas (LNG). It is stated that this new utilization would have consequent risks to the environment.

Directive 82/501/EEC on the control of major accident hazards will apply if the site is used for large‐scale storage of liquified natural gas. This will require that the operator of any such facility takes all necessary measures to prevent major accidents and to limit their consequences and that he receives appropriate monitoring by the competent authority of the Member State.

The Commission was already informed, by a complaint, of the project concerning the area of Montalto di Castro. There has been in 1994 a decision of ‚Consiglio di Stato’ (Supreme Administrative Court) by which the procedure of assessment of the environmental impact of the project is mandatory.

In any case, the Commission will write to the Italian authorities asking information about the application of Directives 82/501/EEC and 85/337/EEC to this project.

The Commission will inform the honourable Member of the European Parliament of the following.

Question No 69 by Rui Vieira (H−0537/96)

Subject: Family policy

Throughout the world and more particularly in the European Union, the place of the family in society is no longer as secure or influential as it should be. Within the Community institutions, the tendency is increasingly to discuss problems, propose programmes and projects and draft measures which would all be more usefully studied, realized and developed if the family were given the importance, protection and support which are its due. There is no doubt that a properly constructed family policy would be an invaluable lever in such policy areas as education, lifelong learning, public health, assistance to children and young people, aid to persons with disabilities and senior citizens, immigrant welfare, cultural development, recreation, support for grassroots associations and even craft work and homeworking.

Even if the main work on family policy must be done at national level, does the Commission not consider that it is time to draw up, on the basis of respect for the principle of subsidiarity, a committed policy for the protection and strengthening of the family, to ensure that this essential and crucial foundation of society is not further weakened and will not disintegrate in the near future?

Answer

In recent years the Commission has undertaken numerous studies of the role of the family in the social and economic context of a changing society. These studies have provided a better understanding of the link between family policy on the one hand and, on the other, questions relating to employment, child support, equality of opportunity and social exclusion. The specialized networks and the European Observatory for Family Policies have contributed to these studies; the results have been extensively discussed within the group of senior officials responsible for family affairs.

In the future, the Commission will be making special efforts to identify further areas in which the family aspect will become more important in the formulation of national policies aimed at promoting comparative analysis and the dissemination of results. The European Parliament will be informed of the main conclusions of this work.

Question No 70 by Gary Titley (H−0541/96)

Subject: Encouraging SMEs to take up EU regional funding

In the light of the recent conference organized by the Greater Manchester authorities, RETI and DGIII on the need for Europe's regions to become competitive, which heard that 60 % to 80 % of SMEs do not take up EU funds available to help them, what action will the Commissioner be taking to encourage smaller companies to use the regional aid they are entitled to?

Answer

The Commission is particularly sensitive to the question raised by the honourable Member with regard to improving access by SMEs to Community regional aid. Measures to support SMEs are contained in most of the Community Support Frameworks. These measures are cofinanced by the European Regional Development Fund and the European Social Fund within National and Regional Operational Programme and by the Community Initiative Operational Programmes, including the SME Community Initiative.

In the course of the period 1989‐1993, about 20 % of the total appropriation was allocated to supporting industry and to services within the Community Support Frameworks (CSFs), although the proportion of this which benefited the SMEs cannot be accurately estimated. The new CSFs adopted for the period 1994‐1999 attach greater importance to the development of the SMEs, especially in the Objective 1 regions (those lagging behind in development). The Single Programming Documents of the Objective 2 regions (declining industrial areas) and Objective 5b areas (rural areas) also include, for the most part, measures in favour of SMEs. Furthermore, the SME Community Initiative, with an appropriation of ECU one thousand million, is specifically designed for the SMEs.

The European Commission, through the medium of the Programme Management Committees, ensures that the resources available under these various programmes are used to the best effect. This includes ensuring that information on the support available is properly disseminated. However, by virtue of the partnership principle governing the Structural Funds, it is a matter not just for the Commission but also, and especially, for the Member States, the regional authorities and the economic and social partners to take action to ensure that the aid programmes are more beneficial to the SMEs. The Commission, which, through the supervisory committees, ensures that the support provided to the SMEs is actually used by them has often argued in favour of greater involvement by the economic and social partners, and especially by the representatives of the SMEs and the crafts sector, in the implementation and follow‐up of the programmes. The Commission also insists that the potential beneficiaries of the programmes, and especially the SMEs, should be better informed of the possibilities offered by the programmes cofinanced by the Community. The 250 Euro‐Info‐Centres distributed throughout the Community help to keep the SMEs informed about these programmes, but the Commission is aware of the essential role played by the competent national regional authorities in creating awareness among the SMEs and providing them with information.

In addition, the European Community is going to support a number of horizontal and transnational actions in the period 1997‐2000, in order to ensure that the experience gained from SMEs which have benefited from Structural Funds is shared in different regions of the Community.

Question No 71 by Frode Kristoffersen (H−0542/96)

Question No 73 by Alan Gillis (H−0545/96)

Subject: Now, Horizon, Youthstart

Given that these projects were assessed for funding in 1995 and finance was allocated to the selected projects under these programmes in January 1996, could the commission please explain the delay in forwarding the funding to the Member States and specifically to Ireland, where small voluntary organizations are paying interest on overdrafts which they have been obliged to take out with banks in order to keep their projects running while awaiting payment for the last six months?

Such delays are responsible for the ‚Bureaucracy’ image which is often unjustifiably given to the Commission; however, in this case such accusations seem justified.

Answer

With regard to the Operational Programme for Ireland under the Employment Community Initiative (comprising NOW, HORIZON, YOUTHSTART), the situation regarding payments can be summarized as follows:

1. A first payment of ECU 3, 605, 000 was made on 29 December 1994.

2. Following the modification of the financial plan presented in December 1995, a further payment was made in March 1996 of an amount of ECU 1, 878, 206.

3. Following a more recent modification of the financial plan a further payment of ECU 8, 387, 032 was made in June 1996 as a first advance payment for the year 1996.

4. A second advance payment of ECU 5, 032, 219 will be possible when the Irish authorities submit the relevant request for payment.

In summary, for a programme representing a total ESF input of ECU 72, 100, 000 agreed for the 6‐year period 1994‐1999, payments amounting to a total of ECU 13, 870, 238 have been made.

The programme also has an ERDF component of ECU 4, 000, 000 or about 5 % of the total. There have been difficulties in making payment for this part of the programme. The Irish authorities have provided the necessary information to allow the Commission to proceed, and a first payment of around ECU 800, 000 will be made within the next few weeks.

Question No 74 by John McCartin (H−0549/96)

Subject: Beef production in the EU

Will the Commission provide the European Parliament with estimates of the amount of beef to be produced in each of the Member States of the EU this year, and will the Commission further indicate whether total production is likely to exceed the requirements of available markets both within the Community and abroad? If so, will such a surplus run counter to agreements entered into in the context of the WTO, and what proposals does the Commission have to deal with any surpluses?

Answer

Before the current BSE crisis broke out forecasts prepared by the Commission indicated a level of production of beef and veal for the 15 of close to 8 million t, more or less unchanged from 1995. Consumption was expected to drop slightly from 7.5 to 7.4 t.

These forecasts have now been revised to take into account the expected BSE impact. The net effect on production is estimated at around 240, 000 t, bringing production down to 7.7 million t for this year, due mainly to the elimination in the UK of older cattle from the food chain. Very preliminary estimates for consumption indicate a drop of more than 10 % for the year as a whole, bringing it down t around 6.6 million t. In addition, certain difficulties on export markets are being experienced. These elements taken together, would imply a surplus for this year exceeding 600, 000 t.

The Commission is currently examining which short term measures can be taken to prevent a further build up of stocks in 1997 and following years.

Question No 75 by Gianfranco Dell'Alba (H−0552/96)

Subject: Environmental impact of the SNAM company's plan to set up a methane gas reception, storage and distribution plant in the port of Monfalcone

The plan to build an LNG (liquified natural gas) terminal in Monfalcone would cause irreparable environmental damage to the area, to its karstic features owing to the planned methane pipeline, and to marine resources, given the large‐scale dredging operations waste disposal would entail.

The building of this terminal, which would employ a very small work force, would be harmful, economically and in terms of jobs, to the fisheries and aquaculture sectors and to existing and potential tourist activities, and would pose a threat to the region's historical and artistic heritage.

The project submitted by the SNAM company would seem to infringe a large number of Community directives on environmental protection.

How and when does the Commission intend to take steps to ensure compliance with all the provisions relating to environmental impact assessments?

Does the Commission not intend to initiate infringement proceedings against any decisions which the Italian authorities may already have taken in this respect?

Answer

The Commission will be sure to inform the honourable Member of the further action taken on these matters.

Question No 76 by Richard Balfe (H−0553/96)

Subject: Global trade and the millennium celebrations

To what extent does the Commission believe the millennium celebrations in the European Community will provide an occasion for the Commission to promote its policies, particularly those connected with increasing European trade opportunities?

Answer

The Commission recognizes the great symbolic value of the millennium and certainly intends to use the opportunity provided by this momentous occasion to participate in actions in the field of culture and information, particularly those highlighting the achievements and objectives of European integration. Among such events where the participation of the Community is already planned are the Universal Exhibition in Hanover on the theme ‚Man, nature, technology’, and the European City of Culture scheme which will be extended to nine cities in the year 2000. Events will also be organized to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration of 9 May 1950. As the Commission informed the honourable Member in its answer to written question No 426/95 (tabled by Mr Balfe and Mr Spiers), it is too early for the Commission to give much more detail about its intentions. However, as the Commission made clear in its reply to oral question 314/95 (tabled by Mr Kerr), it is keeping an open mind and is prepared to look with interest at any proposals for action, including those relating to external aspects and trade.

In that context, the Commission recently issued a Communication setting up a Market Access Strategy to remove unfair barriers in third countries to European trade and investments. European firms are invited to consult the Commission's market access data base, which will be up and running soon, and in particular to raise with the Commission any problems they encounter in selling or investing in third markets. The Commission will then take all possible action to remove unjustified barriers. Secondly, the Commission is currently preparing the WTO Ministerial Meeting in Singapore in December of this year. On this occasion, discussion will take place about the possibility of new negotiations around the time of the millennium to increase trade and investment opportunities around the world. These are ongoing Commission efforts, which are not directly linked to the millennium as such. It is not excluded, however, that specific information actions might be undertaken in the context of the millennium celebrations.

Question No 77 by Raul Rosado Fernandes (H−0554/96)

Subject: Arrangements applicable to property rights in former East Germany

On 5 March 1995 the Commission declared the provisions of the German law of 1 December 1994 (EALG), nominally on compensation, to be in conformity with the Treaty (Articles 92 and 85)

The effect of this law is to release land belonging to the State for sale on highly favourable terms (rebates of 30 to 60 % on market prices) to potential beneficiaries who can in no sense be considered as having been expropriated by the Communist regime in the former GDR.

The main beneficiaries are in fact heads of cooperatives set up by the Communist regime.

This privileged treatment has the effect of creating unacceptable distortions of competition to the detriment of German or Community farmers not designated under the EALG law who would otherwise have been eligible to acquired the land in question.

Will the Commission state for what reasons it failed in this connection to comply with the strict provisions of the Treaty, and does it envisage reconsidering its position on this matter?

Answer

Article 93 of the EC Treaty gives the Commission the right of supervision of state measures as far as they represent state aid according to Article 92(1) EC Treaty. This requires inter alia that the measure produces an advantage in favour of certain undertakings which distorts or threatens to distort competition.

On the basis of information transmitted y the German authorities pursuant to Article 5 EC Treaty in 1995 the law on compensation for confiscation of property has been examined by the Commission. On the basis of information provided by the German government the Commission has come to the conclusion that the law as such does not aim to provide a benefit pursuant to Article 92 EC Treaty, but only provides for compensation of property which has been confiscated by the Russian occupying power between 1945 and 1949. The notification of this measure was therefore considered as unnecessary.

However, the Commission has informed the German authorities that when implementing the law in question measures which go beyond a pure compensation of damage are subject o prior notification. No notification has been received yet.

As the implementation of the law is of special importance in the agriculture sector the Commission has recently requested the German authorities to provide information about the acquiring of agriculture acreage and about the beneficiaries in order to examine if measures in this area go beyond compensation. The answer of the German authorities is still subject of the Commission's examination.

Question No 78 by Jonas Sjöstedt (H−0555/96)

Subject: Swedish regional policy

The European Union gives regional policy support to interregional cooperation between Västerbotten in Sweden and Vaasa in Finland. There has been a long tradition of cooperation and exchanges between the two regions, and the vessels regularly plying between Umeä and Vaasa are an essential link between them. The Union ban on tax‐free sales which is to come into force in 1999 is a threat to this traffic, as well as to other Baltic ferry services. Such sales provide a vital source of revenue to the Baltic shipping lines.

What action does the Commission intend to take to ensure that links which, like that described above, are vital to interregional cooperation, may survive even after 1999?

Answer

Under current Community legislation, duty and tax free sales will end in June 1999. In the Commission's opinion, this decision to abolish duty and tax free sales, taken by the Council in 1991(7) , is consistent with the completion of the internal market.

The Commission recognizes that the ferry services mentioned by the honourable Member are very important for interregional cooperation, especially in peripheral areas of the Community. At present no initiatives are planned at Community level to ensure the continuation of these services beyond 1999. It should be understood that the transition period was agreed in order to allow the industry to take the necessary measures to prevent unwanted social and economic consequences.

More generic programmes concerning interregional cooperation are currently in force under the European Regional and Development Fund. In the framework of a cross‐border cooperation programme entitled ‚KvarkenMittskandia’, which is supported under the INTERREG programme, the regional authorities on both sides of the Gulf of Bothnia (Sweden and Finland) intend to study possible alternative solutions to the present mode of operation of the ferry services in question.

Work is also in progress in the area of the port and short sea shipping elements of the trans‐European transport network. The expected adoption by Council and Parliament of the Decision on the TEN‐Transport guidelines will provide a framework for Community support for port and port‐related projects of common interest.

Question No 79 by Jaak Vandemeulebroucke (H−0557/96)

Subject: The Catalan language

In the light of the European Parliament's resolution of 11 December 1990 on the use of languages in the Community and on Catalan, what measures has the Commission taken to publish Treaty texts in Catalan, disseminate information about the European institutions in Catalan, include Catalan in European language teaching and proficiency programmes, and use Catalan (both verbally and in writing) in its dealings with the public at its offices in the regions concerned?

Answer

1. The Commission favours the publication of the Treaty in Catalan. It is providing financial assistance with the production of this text; it will in any case be an unofficial version.

2. Pursuant to the resolution adopted by the European Parliament on 11 December 1990, the representation in Barcelona has published Catalan brochures, leaflets and videos on the European institutions, programmes and policies. This documentation, intended for the general public, is available from the Barcelona representation.

3. As regards Lingua (Chapter 3, action 1, of the Socrates programme), the eligible languages are defined in the European Parliament and Council Decision(8) establishing the ‚Socrates’ Community action programme, as being the official languages of the European Union together with Erse (one of the languages in which the Treaties establishing the European Communities are published) and Luxemburgish (a language which is spoken throughout the territory of the Grand‐Duchy of Luxembourg).

It is however stated, in the recitals, that the teaching provided in certain languages which have an official status nationally without having the status of an official language of the European Union and which are widely used as teaching languages in the universities should offer opportunities for access to those aspects of the programme which relate to higher education.

As regards the development of linguistic skills under the auspices of the Leonardo da Vinci programme, the promoter's guide adopted pursuant to Council Decision 94/819/EEC of 6 December 1994(9) specifies that the teaching/learning of foreign languages shall be understood to mean the teaching/learning of all the official languages of the European Union, together with Erse, Luxemburgish, Norwegian and Icelandic.

There is, however, a European Commission support scheme for the promotion and safeguarding of regional and minority languages and cultures, and under that head Catalan is an eligible language.

4. Oral and written exchanges between the institution and the population of Catalonia take place in Catalan and Spanish. It should be noted that the language used more frequently is Catalan.

Question No 80 by Peter Truscott (H−0565/96)

Subject: Travel subsidies to EU personnel using airlines that transport primates

The European Parliament spends a large amount of money each year in travel subsidies to Members, a sizeable proportion of which is spent on travel by Air France and Sabena to Strasbourg and Brussels respectively. Is the Commission aware that, unlike over 30 other European airlines, these two companies are still profiting from the transportation of primates? Indeed in recent years it is believed that Air France has trebled its cargo in primates. Given that EU personnel are major users of these two airlines, what measures will the Commission take to dissuade them from continuing this cruel trade?

Answer

The Commission should like to point out that the importation of primates into the Community is subject to legislation on the conservation of the species concerned, on the protection of animals used for experimental and other scientific purposes, on the protection of animals during transport and to legislation in the field of veterinary controls.

Imports are as a result restricted but legally possible. The Commission therefore fails to see why airlines should be dissuaded from transporting primates and other live animals, provided that they transport live animals in compliance with strict Community legislation. The Commission is of the opinion that voluntary refusals by major airline companies to transport live animals are counterproductive in that they cause longer transportation routes, longer transit periods and thus add to the risk of negative effects on the welfare of the animals involved.

Finally, the Commission should like to draw the attention of the honourable Member of Parliament to its proposal for a Council Regulation on the protection of species of wild fauna and flora by regulating trade therein (Doc COM(93) 599 final) on which the Council adopted a common position last May and which is currently before Parliament for a recommendation on second reading. Article 9(5) thereof provides that the transport of any live specimens covered by the regulation (amongst which all primates), their holding in transit and for transhipment shall be carried out such as to minimize the risk of injury, damage to health or cruel treatment and in conformity with Community legislation on the protection of animals during transport. Its Article 16 provides that Member States shall ensure the imposition of sanctions, including provisions on seizure and confiscation, for non‐compliance with the requirements concerned.
