Question No 82 by Ioannis Theonas (H−0576/96)

Subject: Construction of a port at Rafina, eastern Attica

A new port is being built at Rafina in eastern Attica despite strong protests from the local authorities and representative bodies in the area.

The project is funded by the Commission under measure 2.1.3 of the Operational Programme ‚Access and major roads’ under the second CSF. Total estimated investment is in the region of ECU 9.5 million.

The environmental impact assessment for the project is incomplete and, among other things, does not take account of the sea currents in the area, principal among them the ‚great Rafina current’ which ends in the port depositing tonnes of sludge and destroying the work. Local residents, the local authorities and representative bodies also claim that there is a risk of pollution of the town's beaches and they have taken their case to court, which is soon to deliver its judgment.

Will the Commission examine the environmental studies to determine whether they are complete and will it investigate the funding of this project, which will damage the environment in eastern Attica, as requested by the region's local representative bodies?

Answer

The honourable Member refers to work connected with the port of Rafina in Attica (Greece). It is true that the ERDF is cofinancing, under the auspices of the Operational Programme ‚Road Access and Highways’ of the 1994‐1999 CSF for Greece, various work at that port. This work is not connected with a new port but with improving the existing installations, and especially the building of a sea wall to improve the protection of the present harbour in the event of rough weather. The current estimated cost of this work is about ECU 7 million (total cost).

The information obtained by the Commission from the competent national authorities confirms that an environmental impact evaluation has been carried out, in accordance with Directive 337/85/EEC. The impact study would take account of the existence of a small seasonal river. As regards the cofinancing of the works, the Commission does not at present have any information that would justify a position other than that already adopted. To the contrary, the improvement of the port installations at Rafina may help to relieve congestion in the port of Piraeus, which gives these works a degree of priority.

As regards the reexamination of the environmental impact evaluation, the Commission recalls that it regards the expenditure involved in environmental impact studies as an eligible expenditure. Thus, if the competent authorities in the Member State were to make a request for the cofinancing of additional studies for this project, the Commission would, in principle, look favourably upon such a request.

It is however a matter for those authorities to assess the need for an additional environmental impact study and to make any appropriate proposal.

Question No 83 by Bertel Haarder (H−0580/96)

Subject: Japanese ban on pigmeat imports

Against a background of steep rises in imports of pigmeat from Taiwan and the US, the Japanese Government has reintroduced a ban on imports of pigmeat (which is in accordance with the GATT). However, pigmeat imports from the EU have been stable. It therefore seems unreasonable that European pigmeat exports should be hit too.

How does the Commission propose to respond to the reintroduction of the Japanese ban on pigmeat imports, is the Commission giving thought to securing a limited import ban from the Japanese Government by, for instance, making a distinction between fresh and frozen meat or other alternatives, and how does the EU propose to prevent the import ban from becoming permanent?

Answer

The Japanese Government applied the so‐called emergency measures to imports of pigmeat once again on 1 July 1996. This has the effect of raising the gate price applied to imports, effectively excluding Community exports of pigmeat from the Japanese market until 31 March 1997.

This subject has been repeatedly raised by the Commission with the Japanese, in particular at the EC Japan ministerial meeting on 29 April. No positive response has yet been received, and the Commission is continuing to actively pursue a resolution of this matter with the Japanese authorities.

Question No 84 by Mikko Rönnholm (H−0581/96)

Subject: Need for special ‚buffer funds’

European citizens and organizations are considering what attitude to take towards the common European currency. It has been proposed that the Union make use of buffer funds to lessen the impact of excessive distortions arising from the lopsided production structure in the Member States. Does the Commission believe such funds to be necessary? Could sufficient resources be found in the Union budget to finance them, or should the funding be organized by other means apart from agreement between the two sides of industry?

Answer

In the event of country‐specific shocks within a monetary union, budgetary policy may have to play a greater role to cushion such shocks. However, there is no compulsory reason for the centralized budget to be responsible for this greater role.

This is to be linked to the fact that national ‚automatic stabilizers’ are far more important in Europe than they are at the regional level in other big currency unions such as the United States. In this context, national budgets are in most cases sufficient to address temporary problems. The Maastricht Treaty leaves them enough flexibility, provided that a sound discipline is established.

Furthermore, the likelihood of large disruptive asymmetric shocks due to structural differences between Member States should be played down. The European economy is not very specialized on a regional basis. Moreover, in the long run, experience shows that economic integration, instead of implying more concentration, seems to induce more diversification.

Question No 85 by Marie‐Paule Kestelijn‐Sierens (H−0582/96)

Subject: Surgical operations by chiropodists

In some Member States chiropodists are authorized to conduct surgical operations on patients' feet. In Belgium, however, the rule still applies that operations may be carried out only by qualified surgeons.

Can the Commission state in what Member States exercise of the profession of qualified chiropodist is recognized, and in what Member States chiropodists are authorized to conduct surgical operations? Can the Commission give an assurance that, in accordance with the subsidiarity principle, each Member State is free to retain its existing rules on qualifying and practising as a chiropodist, and that it will be required to grant chiropodists freedom of establishment and freedom to exercise their profession only on condition that the profession is exercised in conformity with the rules on qualifications and practice in force in the host country or country of establishment?

Answer

There is no Community definition of the profession of chiropody. Nor is there any specific Community directive harmonizing the conditions for entering that profession and practising it in the Member States on the basis of minimum training conditions.

In the absence of any such specific directive, and it should be noted that similar directives do exist for other health professions, the Member States are free to regulate or not to regulate access to and practice of a profession and to define the minimum level of qualifications required for that purpose.

The Member States must however take due account of the provisions of Community law relating to freedom of establishment and the free provision of services, and of Community Directives 89/48/EEC and 92/51/EEC relating to the general arrangements for recognition of professional qualifications.

In connection with the administration of these two directives, the Commission has just financed a study which relates, in particular, to regulating the profession of chiropody and the appropriate training in the various Member States. A copy of this study will be sent to you for information. It would seem from this study that the profession is not regulated in six Member States of the Community, although some of them do regulate the training.

It is also evident from the study that the only Member States in which chiropodists are allowed to perform certain surgical operations on the feet are Spain, the United Kingdom and Ireland. A chiropodist who emigrates to a Member State where such activities are reserved exclusively to physicians will, of course, have to comply with that restriction.

Question No 86 by José Torres Couto (H−0584/96)

Subject: Fisheries/sardines

The European public has heard, through sundry statements issued by Mrs Emma Bonino and news items in the mass media, of the Commission's aim of reducing the overall size of certain fish catches, in particular sardines, and the consequent reduction in the size of fishing fleets. Could the Commission quantify – and justify – the reductions which have been announced?

Answer

The Commission has proposed to the Council the objectives for the coming Multi‐annual Guidance Programmes, on the basis of scientific advice delivered by a group of independent scientists. The report of this group, commonly known now as the ‚Lassen report’, has been presented to the European Parliament on 15 May 1996.

In the case of the fleets targeting sardines in Atlantic waters off the Iberian peninsula, it is proposed that capacity should be reduced by 30 % in the period 1997‐1999, and by 10 % in the period 2000‐2002. This is consistent with a compromise between the reduction advised by the group of independent scientists and the short‐term reduction of the fishery to the lowest possible level, as recommended by the Advisory Committee for Fisheries Management (ACFM), given the likely adverse consequence of the latter measure.

Question No 87 by Yannos Kranidiotis (H−0589/96)

Subject: Forced child labour in Pakistan

Following allegations by European unions and human rights organizations, the Committee on the Generalized System of Preferences, a Commission body, is considering the possibility of suspending Pakistan from the Community's industrial GSP because of its use of forced child labour.

The GSP Committee has been deliberating ‚in camera’ for a year since June 1995 to determine whether these allegations can be substantiated and then possibly proceed to the next, public stage of proceedings, i.e. conducting an investigation pursuant to Council Regulation 3251/94.

In view of the ILO's unfavourable report on Pakistan (1996), the European Parliament's resolution, the US decision (7 March 1996) on a partial suspension of Pakistan from the American GSP (surgical instruments, sports goods and hand‐woven carpets) as well as the international protests of human rights organizations and the increasing publicity given to the subject by television programmes and reports in the international press, what does the Commission finally intend to do and when?

Answer

The Committee on Generalized Preferences has completed the confidential preliminary phase of its work. The Commission is now moving on to study the data in its possession. The Commission intends to determine as rapidly as possible the action to be taken in this matter, on the basis of the conclusions of this examination and its assessment of the practical and political implications of the matter.

Question No 88 by Jan Andersson (H−0590/96)

Subject: Baltic cooperation and EU relations with Russia

Russia is part of Europe and is its largest country in both area and population. Its development is most important to all countries of the European Union.

The fact that the Baltic is a sea where four Member States, four applicant countries and Russia meet makes the Baltic a very important area. The development of economic, cultural and political cooperation in the Baltic region is essential to the effort to bring the European Union and Russia together. The importance of building rapidly and vigorously on the successful Visby summit cannot be exaggerated.

What role does the Commission believe that Baltic cooperation can play in the EU's future relations with Russia?

Answer

The Commission attaches great importance of Baltic Sea States (CBSS) as a forum where four member states, four associated countries to the Community, Russia, Norway and Iceland meet together with the European Commission, and at the ministerial level also including the EU presidency. This forum discusses in a constructive way issues of common interest. This promotes mutual understanding and no doubt contributes to a positive development, also of the Community‐Russia relations. The Commission's approach to the Baltic Sea region, including Russia, was endorsed by the Florence European Council, i.e. the Council reiterated the importance of the effective implementation of the Community strategy towards the Baltic Sea region. This position was noted with satisfaction by the 5th CBSS ministerial meeting at Kalmar (Sweden) on 2 and 3 July.

Question No 89 by Alex Smith (H−0591/96)

Subject: Nuclear smuggling and trafficking

In the Commission report on the illicit traffic in nuclear materials and radioactive substances, COM(96)171 final of 22 April 1996, it is made clear that some countries have not reported to the Commission all known incidents of nuclear smuggling and trafficking, as is required under the Euratom Treaty. In the light of the new initiative taken at the G7 summit in Lyon on 29 June to combat proliferation and terrorism, what cooperation is planned between the Commission and the United States Government further to the bilateral EU‐USA nuclear agreement of 7 November 1995(10) to ensure a sharing of knowledge on nuclear terrorism between EU and American authorities? What steps will be taken to keep Parliament informed of such developments?

Answer

The Commission informs the honourable Member that regular exchange of information already occurs between the US Departments of State and of Energy and the Commission:

1. In the specific case of combatting the smuggling of nuclear material and radioactive substances, regular contacts have already been established with the United States in the framework of the various meetings and conferences which have been devoted to the subject. Moreover, since one year, the regular meetings which take place between Euratom Safeguards and the US Department of State have taken this problem on board in order to streamline preventive actions and bilateral cooperations.

2. With its status of observer in the G7, the Commission is fully supporting the initiative of the Lyon summit to combat terrorism. Moreover, the Commission has already actively contributed to the establishment of the programme for preventing and combatting illicit trafficking in nuclear materials decided at the G7+1 Summit in Moscow in April of this year. Within its competence, the Commission intends to cooperate with the G7 and any other third country in this field.

It must however be noted that in the more general scope of combatting terrorism, the Commission has no competence in matters such as policing and prosecution actions.

3. As far as the information of Parliament is concerned, the Commission proposes to continue to inform Parliament on a regular basis or whenever requested in the framework of meetings of the Parliamentary committees as it has already been the case over the last two years.

Question No 90 by Niall Andrews (H−0595/96)

Subject: EU freephone on suspected frauds

In order to aid the fight against drugs and economic crime, at the suggestion of Parliament, the Commission set up a phone line in each Member State to enable information to be passed on in complete confidence.

Will the Commission provide a brief report on the experience to date of this system, on a country‐by‐country basis, and will it state, furthermore, what new initiatives have or could be developed in future regarding the EU freephone on suspected frauds?

Answer

The Commission decided in its work programme on the fight against fraud for 1994(11) to install a freephone enabling European citizens to provide information, on a confidential basis, on frauds committed against the Community budget. This system is not intended to include other aspects such as the fight against drugs.

As indicated in its 1995 annual report on protecting the Community's financial interests(12) , the Commission has conducted its first evaluation of the freephone after a full year of practice. This evaluation recognized this additional source of information as useful. More than 200 calls gave rise to a specific follow‐up. On the basis of the inquiries conducted, more than ECU 30 million were involved. In order to guarantee a high level of protection of callers, the Commission does not establish a detailed breakdown of calls by Member State.

The 1996 antifruad work programme(13) indicated that the system would continue to run. It has been extended to Austria, Finland and Sweden. No extension to other areas than the fight against fraud is currently foreseen.

Question No 91 by Per Gahrton (H−0597/96)

Subject: The call from the German Bundesrat for decentralization under the Union Treaty

In a submission to the Intergovernmental Conference the German Bundesrat has called for greater involvement by regions and local authorities in the EU decision‐making process, and proposed that guarantees of genuine decentralization within the EU be enshrined in the Treaty. Similar ideas have been put forward by the Committee on the Regions and the EP Committee on Regional Policy, most recently in the McCarthy report. According to EU‐Magazin (4/96), Commissioner Wulf‐Mathies has expressed opposition to the Bundesrat proposal and claimed that proposals for genuine decentralization in the EU would only serve the interests of the Euro‐sceptics. Is this correct? Is the Commissioner opposed to decentralization and guarantees of regional and local self‐determination of the kind advocated by the Bundesrat, the Committee of the Regions and the Committee on Regional Policy?

Answer

The German Bundesrat, in its document of 15 December 1995, called for a strengthening of regional participation. In particular, it recommended an amendment to the principle of subsidiarity (Article 3b of the EC Treaty), a strengthening of the Committee of the Regions, and a right of appeal to the Court of Justice for the Committee of the Regions.

Mrs Wulf‐Mathies, Member of the Commission, has not expressed any general opinion against the Bundesrat's proposals. In particular, she supported the request for a modification of the composition of the COR with a view to ensuring better legitimation and representation of that body in its dealings with the regions and the citizens. Furthermore, she has always argued in favour of strengthening the advisory role of the COR, especially with regard to certain areas in which the local authorities have substantial powers, representing serious concerns on the part of the citizens. On the other hand, she holds the view that the COR and the regions should not have any jurisdictional verification task of its own with regard to subsidiarity, since this would be contradictory to the Community institutional balance and the advisory nature of the COR.

After all, no institution or body can have an exclusive right to ensure subsidiarity by recognition of the right to bring an action before the Court, on pain of exempting the others from all responsibility. However, according to Mrs Wulf‐Mathies, this does not prevent the committees being able to contribute to an assessment of the implementation of the principle of subsidiarity.

Thus, as regards the Article cited by the honourable Member, and in particular the matter of delimitation of powers, Mrs Wulf‐Mathies has simply expressed her fear that, in the current circumstances, such a list of powers would be reduced to a minimum in the sense that a single Member State would be able to decide upon the progress made by European unification.

Question No 92 by Pat Gallagher (H−0599/96)

Subject: Safety measures on fishing vessels

Will the Commission outline its plans to consult with all sectors of the fishing industry, in addition to the ongoing consultation with Member State governments, in relation to its proposals on the Fourth Multi‐Annual Guidance Programme?

Answer

Consultation of all sectors of the fishing industry is an essential element in the preparation of MAGP. The Commission, therefore organized 35 regional conferences during 1996 in Member States, to discuss progress and problems in fisheries, in relation to MAGP's, with the widest possible range of interested parties.

A socio‐economic report based on the views expressed at these Conferences has been submitted to the Council for their discussions on MAGP 4.

The Commission organized also two meetings (24 January and 21 May) to consult the professionals on European level in the framework of the Advisory Committee for Fisheries.

The Commission also regularly consults on fisheries, including safety measures, in Member States with industry representatives as well as Member State authorities, at Monitoring Committees, within the framework of the Community Programme for fisheries adopted by the Commission.(14)

Question No 93 by Karin Riis‐Jørgensen (H−0600/96)

Subject: EU rules on tendering and the state sickness insurance system in Denmark

The state sickness insurance system covers Danes against sickness in Denmark. However, the scheme covering Danes against sickness abroad, either on holiday or business, is administered by a private sickness insurance company.

Can the Commission confirm that the administration of the state sickness insurance scheme for Danes abroad is covered by the EU Services Directive 92/50/EEC(15) and should therefore be put to tender if the value of the contract exceeds the threshold set in Directive 92/50/EEC?

Answer

The Commission can confirm that the administration of the public health insurance scheme (roughly equivalent to a national health service) abroad is subject to the provisions of Council Directive of 18 June 1992, relating to the coordination of procedures for the award of public service contracts (92/50/EEC) when it is not administered directly by public authorities.

A call for tenders in accordance with the directive is not, however, obligatory for the award of a contract for the administration of the public health insurance scheme abroad, even if the estimated value of the contract is equal to or greater than the threshold provided for in the directive. This is because administrative and operational services in relation to sickness, maternity or temporary disablement benefits under compulsory social security services are classified under the Common Product Classification, reference number 9131, which means that such services are covered by Category 27 (’Other Services’) of Annex 1B to the directive. In accordance with Article 9 of the directive, such contracts, which have as their object services listed in Annex 1B, are subject to two obligations only, namely, the provisions on technical specifications and on post‐award information.

Question No 94 by Nuala Ahern (H−0602/96)

Subject: Nuclear trade with Australia

On 16 June 1996 a cargo of nuclear fuel rods from Australia was unloaded at the Dounreay nuclear reprocessing and waste storage plant in Scotland.

What is the Commission's current policy on the import of spent nuclear rods from technologically advanced countries which as Australia in light of the EU's general policy of the treatment of toxic wastes as close to the point of production as is possible? And will the Commission make representations to the Australian Government to halt further shipments of nuclear fuel to Dounreay?

Answer

The applicability of the proximity principle to radioactive waste management was addressed in the Communication ‚A Community Strategy for Radioactive Waste Management’ from the Commission to the Council, the European Parliament and the Economic and Social Committee in March 1994 (COM(94)66 final). This noted that radioactive waste arisings are much smaller than non‐radioactive, toxic waste arisings and that their treatment will be centralised for economic, safety and environmental protection reasons in a limited number of facilities.

Spent nuclear fuel is imported into the Community for processing under commercial contracts. Such processing takes place in facilities licensed and regulated by the national authorities.

It is the UK Government policy that the waste products arising from the processing of foreign spent fuel in the UK are returned to their country of origin. Such a requirement will likely be incorporated in the commercial contracts.

The Commission has no reason to make representations to the Australian Government concerning the shipments of nuclear fuel.

Question No 95 by Philippe De Coene (H−0605/96)

Subject: Golf courses

The answers to my questions H−0382/96 and H−0503/96 were far from complete. Support has been granted to European golf courses as part of the development of a pan‐European environment management programme for golf courses.

How much money (in ECU) has been spent by the Commission on this programme? Who were the beneficiaries? What criteria were used for allocating the funds?

Answer

Further to reply to oral question H−0503/96, the criteria for funding were established in the Community Programme of policy and action in relation to the environment and sustainable development (Towards Sustainability)(16) , where the Commission plans to grant financial support for general measures to provide information and raise awareness.

The aim of the proposed measures(17) is to help identify the responsibilities and encourage the active participation of the various actors concerned (economic operators, including the trade unions, regional and local authorities, environmental protection organizations and organizations for the defence of consumers) in tackling environmental problems, and also to promote dialogue and cooperation between them.

The European Golf Association Ecology Unit provides exactly these opportunities in relation to European golf that engages some 5.6 million people and involves the management of more than 200, 000 hectares of land, and offers significant opportunities for the development of sustainable behaviour in the matter of water conservation, use of fertilizers and pesticides, and preservation of habitat.

The primary aim of the project was to develop awareness of the environmental attributes of golf courses and to encourage golf clubs and golf facility managers to combine sound golf course management with environmentally responsible methods. The results of this pilot scheme were presented and discussed at an international workshop in Brussels in October 1995, attended by 11 NGOs, the Commission, 11 golfing bodies, and 10 public authorities and specialist groups. The meeting welcomed the results obtained and reached a consensus on the potential benefits of introducing an environmental approach to golf course management, and it was agreed that the EGA Ecology Unit should enter into the necessary dialogue to develop and coordinate a structured Environmental Management Programme for golf‐Europe. The amount of money contributed by the Commission to the European Golf Association Ecology Unit for this project was 99, 400 ECU.

Question No 96 by Tommy Waidelich (H−0606/96)

Subject: Eastward enlargement and the CAP

Eastward enlargement of the EU will create an entirely new set of conditions for the CAP, especially as it will increase the size of the agricultural sector by considerably more than it will increase the size of the EU economy as a whole. This will put a great strain on the EU budget.

What are the Commission's plans and preparations to meet the need for changes in the EU budget, and have the WTO's rules on farm subsidies been taken into account?

Answer

Agriculture has been identified as an important issue for enlargement because of its relative size in some of Central European Countries and because of the difficulties there might be in extending the CAP in its current form to these countries.

In line with the European Council's request at Essen the Commission published last November an agricultural strategy paper which had been preceded by a detailed examination of the agricultural sector in each associated country.

The Commission's strategy paper considered the situation and outlook for producers and production in the Community and the Associated countries; the impact, including the budgetary consequences, of enlargement under the existing CAP; and various options for the future. It assessed expected increases in future productivity; the implications of GATT and the WTO particularly the constraints on tarification and export subsidies, and the need to provide, as far as possible, a smooth integration of future Member States. Taking all these factors into account, the paper concluded that for the next century, further changes to the CAP, developing the approach of the 1992 reform, presented the most appropriate means to allow a competitive European agricultural industry to play a full role in expanding world markets, whilst providing the opportunity for further integration of environmental and rural development policies. The strategy paper (CSE/96/607) has already been the subject of wide discussion within the European Parliament.

In line with the European Council's request at Madrid, the Commission is now examining how, in more practical terms, its conclusions could be developed.

Question No 97 by Mirja Ryynänen (H−0608/96)

Subject: Budget and information funds

The budget guidelines agreed last year stated that the 1997 draft budget would seek above all to continue the moves to rationalize the Union's information policy. The key question where information is concerned is how citizens obtain sufficient knowledge and how the Union operates in relation to citizens.

How will the Commission use the balances left over from Union information campaigns to finance information activities? What has been the outcome of the joint discussions involving four Members of the Commission as well as the Budget Commissioner?

Answer

The European Community's policy on information and communication is designed to enable every European citizen to have easy access to clear and complete information on the activities of the Community and its institutions.

From this standpoint, the Commission and Parliament have already embarked upon a course of rationalizing information and communication activities, and these institutions have been working since 1995 on the basis of cooperation programmes drawn up jointly both by the central services and by the offices and representations in the Member States.

In order to make Community information available locally to citizens, a decentralization scheme is in progress. It primarily takes the form of the development of information staging points and networks covering the entire territory of the Community, and the establishment of contacts with regional and specialized media.

Moreover, this concern for proximity has given rise to the establishment of new instruments of communication (such as the ‚Europe by Satellite ’ service) and the development of electronic means of communication (such as the EUROPA server on the Internet).

The Commission does indeed intend to use the funds currently on the budgetary line and in the reserve for priority information activities (Action on the Euro, ’Citizens First ’ and ‚Building Europe together’). The Commissioners concerned with the implementation of the three priority actions are acting in concert and working together with the representatives of the European Parliament within the framework of the Parliament/Commission advisory working group. The Commissioners are agreed on the broad lines of these schemes. Coordination at Commission level is provided partly by a ‚steering group’ set up for the purpose and partly by DG X, which is an authorizing body for the budget lines relating to these schemes, in collaboration with the departments concerned.

Question No 98 by Robin Teverson (H−0615/96)

Subject: Objective 5a−5b Funding in the UK

The UK Government decided to withdraw European Union Objective 5a funds for England but is continuing the Objective 5a funding programme in Scotland and Wales. In South‐West England, farmers are at present unable to take advantage of existing Objective 5b funding if their project is eligible for Objective 5a funding. Seeing that these Objective 5a funds are no longer available to them, will farmers now be allowed to apply for Objective 5b funding?

Answer

The UK Government has indeed decided to withdraw for England the cofinanced aid scheme for investments in the food processing and marketing industry under Regulation (EEC) No 866/90. The Commission, by its decision of 17 June 1996 has approved this withdrawal. Other measures cofinanced from Objective 5a funds are not affected by this decision. Moreover no change has been made as to the eligibility of projects under Objective 5b programmes.

It is true that investments falling under the processing and marketing scheme of Regulation (EEC) No 866/90 are not as such eligible for cofinancing within the framework of Objective 5b programmes. Therefore, processors who could have applied under the withdrawn scheme cannot automatically transform their demand into an application under an Objective 5b programme. In any case, farmers are not directly concerned by the withdrawal decision taken by the UK Government, since only processors can benefit from the aid scheme under Regulation (EEC) No 866/90.

Question No 99 by Anneli Hulthén (H−0616/96)

Subject: Repayment of VAT

In Sweden mobile telephone users, for example, are being charged double VAT if they use the telephone network in another EU country. The reason is that the arrangements for the reimbursement of VAT between undertakings in various countries within the Community are not working.

What does the Commission intend to do to eliminate this problem?

Answer

The common VAT system does not result in double taxation within the Community. Double taxation is eliminated either by deduction or by a rebate, pursuant to the 8th Directive on the arrangements for repayment to tax‐payers not established within the country (79/1072/EEC).

From the time the system was introduced, the Commission has been particularly concerned to ensure that the repayment procedures have complied with the six‐month period laid down in the directive and do not unreasonably increase enterprises' costs. Thus, it has taken action on several occasions when the periods were deliberately exceeded, initiating the infringement procedures resulting in the condemnation of such practices (cf. cases C−287/91 and C−16/95).

The Commission has found a solution to this problem in its communication on a common VAT system and a programme for the single market. The proposed new system for VAT is based on the principle of taxation at source. Under this system, the tax would be deducted totally by the tax‐payer by offsetting against the total tax due, irrespective of the place in which the deductible tax has been paid. Thus the entire specific repayment procedure laid down by the eighth VAT Directive would lapse.

Question No 100 by David Bowe (H−0617/96)

Subject: European trading interests

In the light of the planned expansion of the American listening base at Menwith Hill in North Yorkshire, is the Commission confident that the increased capacity to intercept electronic communications will be used to the mutual benefit of both US and European Union trade and economic interests?

Answer

Question No 101 by Arthur Newens (H−0433/96)

Subject: Incidence and treatment of osteoporosis

Can the Commission provide any information on the incidence and treatment of osteoporosis in the Member States of the European Union and will it be prepared to assist efforts made by organizations such as the UK Osteoporosis Society to encourage research and measures to combat this disease which leads to pain, disability and premature loss of life in significant numbers of people?

Answer

Osteoporosis is an important problem in public health. Women but also men suffer from osteoporosis, which is mainly associated with ageing. More than one third of the women aged 50 and over will suffer in their life from a hip, vertebral or wrist fracture. This situation may be expected to become worse as the population ages.

Hormone replacement therapy (HRT), calcium supplementation with adequate vitamin D, and a good exercise programme to maintain bone and muscle strength are still the most important means of both prevention and treatment of osteoporotic patients.

Within the context of the programme on health promotion, information, education and training, the Commission is examining the issues of osteoporosis. It is expected that a report will be available which will cover recommendations for professionals, the decision makers and the public. It will also help to determine the best actions to undertake at Community level.

The BIOMED programme is actively promoting research on osteoporosis under the subarea for chronic and age‐related diseases.

Four networks of leading European research institutes are being funded, with 67 laboratories participating (1, 4 MECU total budget). These groups, coordinated from UK, France and the Netherlands, are trying to resolve the reasons for the growing trend in osteoporotic fractures and the large variation in the incidence of osteoporosis across Europe. For example, calcium intake mechanisms and ultrasound screening methods are being studied.

The next opportunity for Member State scientists to submit new proposals for research on this area is on December 17th, 1996 (BIOMED−2 third call).

Question No 102 by Anne McIntosh (H−0442/96)

Subject: Boats under 12 metres long and the CFP

Will the European Commission amend the common fisheries policy to ensure that the rules with respect to quotas are applied on an equal footing in all Member States?

In France, boats under 12 metres do not count against quota. It seems only fair that there should be a reciprocal arrangement for Britain and other Member States of the European Union.

Will the European Commission ensure that this imbalance is redressed?

Answer

The system of quota management applies equally to all Member States. In accordance with the dispositions of Title II (Articles 6 to 19) of Council Regulation (EC) No 2847/93(18) , Member States should register and communicate to the Commission all landings or transhipment made in the area under their sovereignty or jurisdiction. This obligation includes the landings made by the smaller vessels.

On the other hand, the obligations and modalities of declaration and recording of landings depend on the size of vessels, but are also applicable to all Member States on an equal footing.

The Commission, therefore, does not find any imbalance or unfair treatment in this issue as British fishermen are concerned.
